arm_group.description: those with an Invisalign® Treatment for orthodontic correction
those with braces for orthodontic correction.

brief_summary.textblock:
This study aims to compare the pain experienced by patients undergoing orthodontic treatment
      with Invisalign ® corrective aligners  with that of patients undergoing orthodontic
      treatment with conventional braces. Because the aligners are removable, nearly invisible and
      don't involve metal that can irritate teeth and gums, we are expecting less pain in the
      Invisalign Treatment and less affectation of the quality of life.

clinical_study.brief_title: COMPARISON OF THE PERCEPTION OF PAIN BETWEEN ORTHODONTIC TREATMENT WITH Invisalign ® AND TREATMENT WITH BRACKETS

detailed_description.textblock:
The aims of the study are to determine:

      the presence of pain, the magnitude of pain, the duration of pain, and the location of pain.

      The hypotheses of this study are:

        -  Treatment with Invisalign ® aligners result in less pain than the braces

        -  Treatment with Invisalign ® aligners result in less irritation to the soft tissues with
           braces

        -  Pain should increase each time the aligners are put in the mouse  and decrease until
           disappearing on the third day.

        -  The quality of life will be most affected by treatment with braces  than with
           Invisalign ®.

        -  Null Hypothesis: There is no difference at all points between the two treatments.

study_pop.textblock: Patients are recruited from the Department of Orthodontics at the University of Montreal.

facility.name: clinique d'orthodontie de l'Université de Montréal

clinical_study.official_title: COMPARISON OF THE PERCEPTION OF PAIN BETWEEN ORTHODONTIC TREATMENT WITH Invisalign ® AND TREATMENT WITH BRACKETS

primary_outcome.description:
A questionnaire will be completed by the patient at different time points during treatment.
This questionnaire includes questions on descriptive pain: location, duration, alteration in quality of life and a visual analog scale (VAS).

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

responsible_party.investigator_title: Associate professor, Doctor of Dental Medecine

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Case Control, Time Perspective: Prospective
